page.title: 08Farming & Ecology
page.content: This area of Suffolk is often referred to as the "Prairies of East Anglia". Since the second World War ended in 1944 there has been a gradual removal of the hedgerows by the farmers to enlarge the field units to make them easier to farm. This has required high mechanisation and low labour force. The price the area has had to pay is a rather monotonous vista of cereal and rape crops. A number of farmers are planting trees as wind breaks to stop soil erosion and snow drifting in the winter which has frequently caused Hundon to be cut off - sometimes for days. Weed and pest control has been taken over by aerial spraying using light aircraft. One farmer in the centre of Hundon at Street Farm (David Claydon) has 3 aircraft at the rear of his farm with a grass landing strip.
